title: RS22607
content: It is a federal crime to assault, kidnap, or kill a federal judge or their family members with the intent to obstruct or retaliate against the judge's duties. The law also protects federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and any federal officer or employee. Penalties are based on the seriousness of the offense. Section 207 of P.L. 110-177 increases the maximum penalties. The law protects federal officers, prosecutors, and anyone assisting them from threats, assaults, kidnappings, or killings related to their federal duties. Penalties for obstructing offenses are based on the seriousness of the crime, with increased maximum penalties under Section 207 of P.L. 110-177 for voluntary and involuntary manslaughter. This amendment extends to various federal jurisdictional circumstances, including the killing of federal judges, officers, employees, and witnesses for federal proceedings. The amendment extends protection to federal judges, officers, employees, and witnesses under federal obstruction of justice statutes. Penalties for crimes against federal witnesses are the same as for federal officials, with increased penalties for assault and conspiracy. Sections 205 and 206 of P.L. 110-177 increase the maximum penalty for witness tampering involving physical force from 20 years to 30 years. The penalties for crimes against federal witnesses, including witness tampering and retaliation, have been increased under Sections 205 and 206 of P.L. 110-177. The maximum penalty for witness tampering involving physical force has been raised from 20 years to 30 years, with increased penalties for threats of physical force and harassment as well. Additionally, Section 204 adds a venue provision for prosecution of witness retaliation offenses. The Constitution may limit Section 204's reach, as indicated by the Supreme Court. Federal criminal prohibitions target violence against federal officials, witnesses, and proceedings, as well as the misuse of firearms and explosives. For instance, 18 U.S.C. 930 prohibits using a firearm or dangerous weapon in a fatal attack in a federal facility, with penalties for murder, manslaughter, attempted murder, or conspiracy to murder. Possession of such weapons can result in imprisonment for up to 5 years. One federal statute, 18 U.S.C. 930, prohibits the use of firearms or dangerous weapons in federal facilities, with penalties for murder, manslaughter, attempted murder, or conspiracy to murder. Possession of these weapons can lead to imprisonment for up to 5 years. Additionally, possession of firearms or dangerous weapons within a federal courthouse can result in imprisonment for up to 2 years. Section 203 of P.L. 110-177 expands the prohibition to include possession of other dangerous weapons as well. Section 203 of P.L. 110-177 expands the prohibition to include possession of other dangerous weapons as well, defining "dangerous weapon" broadly to cover various objects that could be misused for serious injury. The definition of "dangerous weapon" in federal facilities includes objects that could be misused for serious injury, leading to potential practical problems in enforcement. It is a federal crime to threaten or harm federal officers, employees, their families, witnesses, or jurors to impede their duties. Aiding or abetting in these crimes incurs criminal liability. It is a federal crime to make publicly available certain identifying information of federal officials, employees, witnesses, and jurors with the intent to threaten or incite violence.
